Big, fluffy lion.

Hello, Ollie.
Hello.

Am I not on fire?

You ready?

Well, I prefer when the lights are off.
Yeah, I think I prefer when the lights are off as well.
Maybe we could ask Ollie if he could turn the lights off.

He's a very good friend of mine.

Thanks, Ollie.
Jamie, maybe you should have a wander round and check out the studio.
This is, this is, honourate it.

I'm going to take my headphones off so I won't get a hear you.
So, this should be a blast.
So, Jamie has taken his headphones off.

So, I'm running my fingers around the outside of the room.
And I found the seam in the wall.
I wonder what's behind there.
And I'm just running my head around the outside.
So, I get an idea from the sides of the space.
And it also means that I tend to find things that I might not have noticed.
So, I'm now stood behind Robin.
I promise I won't eat you.
Or eat him breakfast.
That's good.
There's a white board in here for some reason.

Is this helping Jamie?
I think it does. It helps me get an idea for the space.
And we've already adjusted things like the lights.
So, I'm going to pop my headphones back on
and then come back into the radio world.
You're listening to 1800 Seconds on Autism.
Recently, I read your blog on network autism
where you were talking about your support.
And I know that you have paid support and support for friends.
Maybe you could tell us more about what that means in your daily life.
Yeah, sure.
The way that they're really great actually.
So, a couple of years ago, I got into a bit of a sticky situation.
I was really struggling to live alone and I was very ill as I think, you know.
And I got a flat nearby.
And it was very quickly apparent that I wasn't going to live on my own.
Weirdly, at first, they did all the support.
But they needed help.
So, we literally found a babysitter.
We just went on to findababicitter.com and went,
we've got a nautistic adult who needs help with dinner.
We foundababicitter.
And she came and started my evening routine.
And then kind of over time, my evening routine evolves and I got paid support
to help me with dinner, bath,
all that sort of stuff, laundry.
And then my friends provide the more kind of adventure support.
It's kind of important to me that my friends are friends, not carers.
Do you ever get this with things where you find that the care element of a relationship
makes it a bit complicated?
I wouldn't use a friend as a carer.
Because of that, because it's important to keep in separate.
Do you mind having a babysitter?
Doesn't it make you feel like a child or you don't mind?
I don't mind. The lady was really nice.
She worked in a special school.
So, what she did is actually, in a way, a lot of, at that time,
I really needed someone to help me structure things.
And that's what she did all day at school.
So, we put together routines, visual timetables, etc, etc.
These days, I tend to use a more traditional care agency because I've got a care budget.
And they're nice.
It's a different thing.
Professional care is different from friends.
Over time, I'm looking forward to when the care is more isolated from friends.
Because then I can, you know, have spent time with my friends being friends.
Does that make sense?
Yeah. I don't really have a lot of care.
I have lots of difficulties doing doing everyday things because of my...
I have...
Well, if you count autism as a disability, then I have 10 disabilities.
But if you don't count autism, then I've got 9.
Personally, I count autism, but not everybody would.
Things like cooking.
For a long time, I just sort of lived off ready meals or if my parents sent me a food parcel.
But recently, I've been using a recipe box service.
And that's been really helpful.
I've tried a couple, but I can only really cope with six instructions.
And they need to be clear.
And I need photos that are big and taken with a bit of perspective,
rather than taking as a bird's eye view, or as you would see it being a person doing a cooking.
That's interesting.
Cooking is this collection of steps, isn't it?
And then the instructions are never complete.
Many years ago, I was living somewhere.
And I'd been on trains a lot.
And you get on a train, but really you get in a train?
Anyway, I'd been making these pizzas in a microwave.
And this carrot, I say to the carrot, all these pizzas, they're bloody awful.
They're so crunchy, they make my teeth hurt.
I can't finish a whole one.
Actually, if you're like, oh, well, you know, we know you like them,
so try them for another day.
And then finally, somebody stopped to watch what I was doing.
And I'd confused in and on.
So I was following the instructions to the letter.
I was walking up to the microwave, opening the door,
putting the pizza on top of the microwave, closing the door and turning on the microwave.
Because I'd mixed up in and on from these trains.
So I also get this thing where,
unless instructions are incredibly clear and understand the concepts, I really struggle.
With the cooking, I actually, I think I go the opposite way to you.
I see cooking as a thing, I see food as a thing that has to happen.
And I want to get it done and out the way as efficiently as possible.
And I think if I had to prepare a meal every day, an evening meal,
I probably wouldn't have the energy left to work and do the things I do well.
So that's one of the reasons why we have support for it.
Because they can do in 10 minutes, but it'll take me 45 minutes
and ruin me for the rest of the day.
Yeah, I mean, cooking for me could be difficult,
because, yeah, it does take up a lot of spoons.
You know, it does take up a lot of...
Actually, I've got some spoons here.
Shall we explain spoons?
Oh, yeah, explain spoons.
Okay.
So these are spoons.
These are physical spoons, but spoons are actually in analogy.
So let's pretend that we had a two-spoon day.
I'm Satopasit, Robin.
Hey, Robin.
Hi.
So if I've slept really well, I get 10 spoons a day,
but let's pretend that Robin is slept well.
Hey, Robin, here's two spoons.
Thanks.
Now, Robin's got the spoons because she slept well.
And whatever she does during the day,
costs spoons.
So for example, hey, Robin,
are you going to cook a meal tonight?
Yeah, I think that's going to cost two spoons, to be honest.
Oh, okay.
There's a lot of spoons.
So I've got any spoons left now.
So therefore, Robins run out of energy.
Yeah.
Do anything.
So spoons are a metaphor for managing energy.
I also was sometimes referred to it as like battery charge.
And the thing about a lot of autistic people,
and certainly myself,
I, even if I sleep really well, I only get 10 spoons a day.
And things like crossing the road might take half a spoon.
Certainly getting here this morning took three spoons.
So I need to very carefully manage that budget.
It's a bit like miss spending by a pound
when you've got 10 pounds versus miss spending by a pound
when you've got 100 pounds.
So that's what spoons are, if you're wondering.
And we happen to have some spoons in the room right now.
So I'll put these down, because they're quite loud.
Yeah, so I only cook three nights a week,
but it could be a little weekend.
But then when I've done that,
I really struggled to say, do the washing up or...
And it depends a lot on the recipe, like that.
The recipes are sort of familiar things.
They're a lot less work.
A lot less spoons, like sausage and mashed potato,
is less spoons because it has relatively small number of steps.
And you don't have to wait for many things.
That a lot of the recipes involved waiting are not they good at waiting.
We should have a campaign for clearer instructions.
Yeah, well, the one that also gets me is also, you know,
doing till cooked.
Well, what does cooked look like?
You mentioned sausage and mash.
That's actually one of the meals I can make.
But the way that I do it is I have the sausage stick.
And it's a brown stick that's in my kitchen.
And when the sausage is the same color as the brown stick, it's cooked.
And that's kind of like my only real way of telling these things.
Sausages are fine, easy, but only because the sausages I buy are really lean.
And I don't mind if they're slightly burnt on the top,
because that way I at least know that they're cooked properly.
But I did once burn some mince in a bolognese,
and that was pretty horrible.
I set fire to a lump of lamb once.
Which was slightly alarming.
I had to call a friend and go, I had a small fire.
How did you do it?
How did you catch?
I left it in an oven,
and then kind of noticed fire coming out of the oven.
Which didn't seem like a thing that should happen.
So I pulled it out and threw it on the floor.
And then was like, wait, now I'm just spreading the
now the fires out of the oven.
That's probably not a good idea.
So I threw a towel over it, which turns out to be the right thing to do,
which was lucky.
Do you know what a lamb afterwards was delicious?
But I probably shouldn't cook it that way in the future.
Actually, since then, I've not cooked any lamb,
because it's kind of terrified me of it.
Chickens are another good point as well.
And when they say, like, poke-kick it until the juices run clear,
I don't have a clue what that means.
It's like, do I pick it up and squeeze it?
I know I'm like meant to stab a hole in it.
Do I stab a hole?
You know, there seems to be all this implied knowledge.
Like, if you're stabbing a hole in it,
you need to stab it in a certain place,
or a certain hardness,
or a certain type of fork.
And in my day to day life, I can make more good in the world,
because that's my goal.
My goal is to make things good,
you know, use my skills as much as I can.
I don't have cooking skills. They're not there.
So if I can use my technology skills to build things to help other autistic people,
but I accept that somebody else is going to help me cook,
or somebody will just cook it for me, that's fine.
So I think we can agree that we've both had
difficulties with the instructions not being clear enough.
Do you think there ought to be a campaign
or something to make them clearer?
See, there already is.
And there's this thing called the Crystal Market.
It's a standard for written communication.
You can't have to see it on bank letters and stuff.
And they certify things.
But it's really hard to set these sort of clear language guidelines,
because language maps to concepts.
And if you don't understand the underlying concept,
then the language will never make sense.
Something that the government digital service do,
who make all of the government websites.
I think they have a list of all words
that are expected to be known by an eight-year-old.
And they try and design everything to only use words from that list.
And they have some really nice clear writing things.
So all sentences under 25 words,
you know, words from this list.
So I think that helps.
In fact, the digital communication guidelines
called the Wicag actually now from this year onwards
include simplified content as one of the success criteria.
So, you know, autistic people are being listened to,
but I don't know if there's any autistic involvement with Gleermark.
Do you think that it would stop you eating a frozen pizza frozen?
I'm not sure if it would have,
because at that time I was really struggling,
and I'd inverted the words in and on in my head.
So no amount of pointing out to me would have noticed it,
because I'd misunderstood the concept.
And I find this often happens to me.
And for years, I thought that fireman Sam,
the fire escaped, and he went and caught it and brought it home.
Because if you watch the episode,
there's nothing that actually stops you from believing that.
And because he was a fireman,
I assumed he would walk around on fire.
So that sort of literalism can be very difficult to capture.
I needed to be shown not told,
and I think that happens quite often.
And in fact, in my day-to-day life,
when I have the carers, I give them the permission to tell me to do things.
Because as soon as someone starts asking me to do things,
I tend to get a bit muddled up,
and I'm not sure what they mean.
Do you ever get that when people say,
oh, would you like to do do do?
Or like, would you like to have a bath?
You know, is that an instruction go and have a bath?
Because I smell.
Or is that a genuine question?
Would I like to have a bath?
Or would I prefer a shower?
You know, the context isn't there for me.
Do you ever get that?
I tried hard to learn about context.
There's a book by Peter van Mooleon called Autism as Context Blindness.
Because most non-autistic people communicate within context.
So I tried to learn to be able to think my way out of it.
But my mom did tell me once to go and put some bread in the toaster,
which I did.
And then about five minutes later,
she asked, had it popped up yet?
And I said, no, because you asked me to put it in the toaster.
And she said, oh, I meant put it in the toaster and pull the handle down.
But now I know that.
I'll remember to pull the handle down.
The trouble for me is I don't remember those things.
And I have, there are so many of them
that I just can't really keep a database of them in my head
of every single little weird thing I need to remember.
And I tend to make the same mistakes multiple times.
And people think that I will learn by getting it wrong.
And I tend not to.
The way that normally works for me is to modify the environment in somehow,
in some way.
So for example, for a while, I was going out without my shoes on.
So we put a big thing on the back of my door, saying, you know,
wear shoes, kind of like a checklist.
And we followed it this morning, leaving the flat,
that's, you know, shoes, watch, ear defenders, etc.
Although we did have this idea that we should pull up my rug
and put some Lego in front of the door.
So if I try and go out without shoes on, I'll know about it
because my feet were hurt.
So that sort of thing, modify the environment to tell me what I need to do,
rather than try and expect me to remember things.
How far from home did you get without shoes?
I've got all the way to the end of the street without shoes before.
I've actually got all the way to the end of the street,
picked my foot up, pulled a stone out of my foot,
and then noticed I wasn't wearing shoes.
I sometimes can't fill my feet.
They're a bit dodgy.
So it's surprisingly hard to notice if we've got shoes on or not.
Do you ever worry that you're going to, like, forget your door keys or something?
I forget my door keys quite often.
So within a five minute walk of my flat,
there are three people with door keys.
And I also have access to people via chat systems,
so that I always have some backup options available.
Oh, I think Ollie fell off the chair or something.
I think Ollie's chair broke.
Oh.
Yeah, I think he broke a little bit.
The chair broke a bit.
Are you falling asleep?
No.
Carries do this often, they fall asleep.
So busy.
Because if you think about it,
How much responsibility is there?
Yeah, it's a hell of a responsibility.
So he's got me here safely this morning,
and I haven't got run over, which is, you know, good.
But it does mean that he has to be very aware of things,
and in a way, there's kind of this balance of,
I know that by accessing support,
I'm making my impairments affect other people.
But as long as it's an equitable setup, you know,
Ollie's paid for his time, it's a fair pay.
And there's a genuine win-win situation,
then I think it's okay.
If I didn't have any support,
I would probably just about live independently.
But there's no way I'd be working.
I'd just be a stressed out,
incredibly tired, all the time, muddled up mess.
So the little bit of support that's there
really does support my life.
Coming soon to 1800 seconds on autism,
I think I was trying to do the normal thing,
and it wasn't working for us.
So I was taking him to those god-awful music groups
that you take toddlers to, which were absolutely healthy, my son.
He was trying to escape, I now realise.
What is it in particular that makes you interested in Doctor Who?
Big question.
It's okay, don't worry.
Our producer, Damon, is neurotypical,
and that was a neurotypical phrased question
that I was just repeating back, sorry.
I've come to the conclusion that we're all like light switches.
We're either on or we're off.
We either love something totally or totally hate it.
Yeah, that's an interesting poem.
And I like several parts of it,
although one part of it is sticking in my memory quite strongly.
LAUGHTER
Robin fell off the chair.
Oh, he's hot.
Here more from Jamie and Robin
by subscribing to the show on BBC Sounds.
Send any questions or thoughts to
Stim at BBC.co.uk.
Well, we're settling down nicely in our studio, aren't we, Jamie?
Yeah, quite like it.
It's nice and dark, lovely people, lovely time, all good.
Hey, Robin, you asked me about my keys.
Is there any reason why you asked about keys?
Well, because if you're not wearing shoes,
then that probably means you haven't gone for your routine for going out.
And if you haven't gone for your routine going out,
you might not have your door keys,
but you need to get back in to get your shoes.
To keep your feet safe from stones.
And, yeah, so I have a short routine when I leave my flat,
that before I close the door,
I check that I've got my keys by tapping them,
like that,
and that my phone's in my pocket by tapping my right pocket.
And if it's hard, and that means my phone is there,
it feels a certain way.
And then I tap my left pocket,
and that feels a certain way.
And that's where my ball is.
And that feels a certain way.
And that's where my ball is.
So I do that every time before I leave my flat,
before I close the door, just a double check,
I have my keys and my phone and my wallet,
because I know that I need those three things to really be able to survive.
But it always gives me a lot of anxiety about,
you know, forgetting those kind of things.
You're lucky to live near loads of people that you know.
It wasn't luck. We set it up on purpose.
The whole idea is that I live in an environment where,
if I have a really, the way that we've built it,
is if I have the worst possible day I can have,
which is no speech, no ability to communicate at all,
really struggling with a panic attack or something,
the support is in the environment.
Now, in my life, the way that we have it set up at the moment,
is that I have support overnight.
This is again one of those trade-offs of the cost-in spoons,
basically, if I'm alone overnight,
I'm not going to gain any spoons.
And if I'm not gaining spoons,
then there's nothing else I can do.
So for now, we're putting the support in place overnight.
Now, my hope is that by the end of the year,
I won't need it. So I'm currently in the process of moving home.
And as I'm moving home,
we're trying to change the environment as much as possible
to make things safer, to make things more comfortable.
So a good example of this would be we're fitting fire doors,
so that if there is a fire,
it is actually safe for me to stay in my room.
We're also doing things like,
I have Piper line set up,
which is like an emergency response button
that goes through to a call centre.
And we have them set up that if I move at them,
it means everything's okay.
If I press the button, then they don't hear anything,
then they send somebody.
I'm never a good judge of when it's an emergency.
So if I hit the Piper line three times in one night,
because I'm ill, they don't care,
I don't care.
Again, we just recover from fire quickly.
But that's why it doesn't go to friends.
It goes to a call centre.
Why did you choose move as a sound?
Because I can say move even when I'm nonverbal most of the time.
Move is one of the few noises I can make
when I'm really struggling with speech.
It's also really clear over a telephone.
So if I move at you,
it generally means everything's okay.
Do you ever get that word just kind of dribble out
or by themselves,
and then you need to kind of try and stop them from all falling out?
It's like words all over the floor
and then you feel like you're going to have to clear up a mess.
I occur earlier sometimes when I'm particularly,
when I'm stressed,
which means that I repeat things like
mind with the gap.
Yeah, a collier is repeating things.
I used to do it, I'll bless my friends.
So now I said that one of my friends is called Tabby.
And when I was really struggling with my speech,
the first speech that I got back was bad Tabby,
which was something that someone had said to him
when he spilled a drink,
but I echoed it back to them over and over and over again.
I got the same thing with Thomas the Tank Engine line sometimes,
and then I was like,
I'm going to have to go back to the first speech
and think about it.
And I think that Thomas the Tank Engine line sometimes
is that very occasionally,
if I'm really stressed,
I'll spit out some random Thomas the Tank Engine dialogue
from 20 years ago.
So some people say that echo earlier,
it's just something that happens when you're a child,
but we both experience it as adults.
Yeah, it's just part of being autistic.
It's the same as like stimming when I flap
and other bits and bobs.
Do you have, I get this feeling sometimes
when if I can't pick words,
I can kind of defaults to the nearest communication.
So for example, most of the carers in my life
have never heard me speak,
which is why it's a bit odd when I give them this podcast link,
because they haven't normally heard my voice.
But if they get, when they arrive at the door,
the best I can normally squeeze out is an,
hello, or a ulaah,
it's just the word that will come out.
But very occasionally,
if something's going very well,
they'll get a little bit of a collier out of me.
And I think part of it is
because they're very important people in my life
that I'm very dependent on.
And I know that communicating the wrong things
can be easily misunderstood.
There's a bit of an anxiety there.
My speech has been on and off for ages.
So it's not anything new.
And for the most part, we just ignore it.
We just let it happen.
Because eventually it's like building up momentum.
It'll start off as a bit of a collier.
Or many years ago, I think we did an event together.
We're a temple grandin'
and I started my presentation by reading a poem.
Because the poem got my speech going
and a bit of momentum up.
And then I could start picking my own words.
So speech is something I find quite difficult,
which is kind of ironic considering
I make podcasts and do public speaking
as part of my job.
How do you find speech, Robin?
I'd say 99% of the time I have speech.
Only if I'm very ill,
I tend to go there quiet.
And so when I got diagnosed
with a well-balanced syndrome,
I went to the doctors complaining of a double-known pain.
And they said that I should go to A&E if it continues.
And I thought, well, that's not going to be
for an autistic person, A&E.
And autism on their own.
And that sounds like a bad combination.
So I went to my parents
because my parents kind of act like a triage.
Yep.
Because my friends do the same.
Yeah, so I went and
yeah, my parents knew as soon as they saw me.
Definitely something wrong with you.
Because you've gone grey.
And you're not speaking very much.
Definitely something wrong.
Not sure if you've got appendicitis,
but totally see that there's something wrong.
And so they got me a GP appointment
and they took me because I needed someone to advocate.
I couldn't understand the questions.
I needed the questions rephrased.
Exactly the same as basically any time I go to the doctor,
I go with a friend or with a support person.
Because that's the time when I need to be able to communicate most.
That's the time when I need to be able to communicate most accurately.
But by definition, I'm at least able to communicate.
It's actually kind of interesting because you have to have a lot of trust
in the other person's ability to read you.
And that can take years and years and years to develop.
And you know, it takes a long time.
Yeah, so then the doctor said that I had
a little ball syndrome
and she gave me some medication for it.
And then that made a lot of difference.
Like, as soon as I took it, I went to sleep.
And then when I woke up,
I was much better.
But I wasn't cute.

Like, I can't vision them in space.
There's another reason why I walk around rooms.
Because when you walk around rooms, you actually find where the real corners are.
Because in this room you've got gray in all the corners.
And it can, in one moment, feel like it's expansive and 100 miles wide.
And then the next moment feel like it's a tiny little box.
So having that reference of how big the room is is something that's really helpful for me.

My hands.

we actually deny autistic people bodily autonomy, you know, control over our own bodies.
